YOUR
FIRST
FLIGHT
Tim very glad you're planning to join the more
than five million people who fly TWA each year!
heres must none mike an tavel to ser vou were
you're going swiftly, comfortably, and conveniently. It
enables you to make the most of your vacation time ...
see more of vour tamiv anderiends get more done
on business trips.
You've
probably been wondering just what it's like to
travel by air, and exactly what you can expect on your
first flight. Suppose I describe a typical TWA flight for
you. Let's say you're about to take off for Europe, or on
a trip in the U.S. Your bags are packed, your reserva-
tions confirmed, and you're ready and eager to go! Be
sure you know what time vonhave to me at the ticket
counter. and get there in plenty of time
Check-In Time
First you "check in" for your flight by taking your
ticket and baggage to the agent at the downtown or
airport ticket counter. He'll tear a coupon off and put
your flight number on the envelope. Show this envelope
to vour Hostess when vou board vour plane.
If you're travelling on TWA Constellations or Jet-
streams First Class, you may select your seat on the
plane from a seating plan when you check in at the
ticket counter. On Tourist or Coach tights the rule is
nirst come. nirst served - select vour seat alter you ve
stepped aboard the plane. Preferences about seats differ;
to look out of the window choose a seat in the rear
of the plane.
At the airport. listen for a departure announcement.
The announcement will give your flight number and
destination city and will tell you which gate to go to.
A Word About Your Baggage
Your baggage will be tagged at the ticket counter,
and wilhe checked through to vour desanation when
you check in at the downtown or airport counter. It
will be waiting for you to pick up in the baggage arrival
area at the airport when you arrive on flights within
the
J. S..
or latte internationa customs counter on
Tights overseas.
When you're packing, be sure to keep in mind your
tree baggage allowance: 40 los. on nights within the
U. S., 66 lbs. on international First Class flights, and 44
lbs. on international Tourist and Economy Class flights
To avoid excess baggage charges, it's a good idea to
weigh your baggage on the bathroom scale before
you go.
If you must have excess baggage, the charge is 1% of
the First Class adult one-way fare per kilogram (2.2 Ibs.)
on international flights. and one halt of 1% of the adult
First Class
one-wav fare per pound on flights in the
U.S. These charges apply for all classes of service
Your coat, umbrella, pocketbook, magazines and books,
and small cameras do not count as baggage, and you
may carry them aboard your plane without having them
weighed.
Your Hostess will take care of your coat
Welcome Aboard!
Before taking off, and again before landing, you
will be asked to fasten your seat belt, and the
"No
Smoking" sign will flash on. At all other times when
the plane is in the air, you may smoke as many ciga-
rettes as you want. Out of consideration for
passengers, cigar and pipe smoking is discouraged on
board
The Hostess will offer you chewing gum before you
take off. Chewing or yawning helps to relieve air pres-
sure changes.
You can draw the window curtains to cut off light, if
you wish. Your Hostess will remove the center arm of
the seat, it you have no seat companion, so you car
stretch out more freely. There is an overhead rack for
your hat, and a handy push button for your individual
reading light.
Relax-and enjoy your flight! You'll find it easy to ad-
reclining
which you're most comfortable, using a convenient
lever on the arm of your seat. Watch the scenery below
through the big picture windows. And when you get
tired of sitting in one place, get up and stretch your legs
-it's perfectly all right to stroll up and down the aisle.
On First
Class flights. vou're welcome to
the
Tounse
You'll find a drinking fountain located near the door
of the plane, and several lavatories on board, each
complete with well-lighted mirrors for prettying up, and
supplied with soap and cleansing tissues for your use.
By all means explore the plane-but we have to call the
flight deck or cockpit up forward out of bounds. Gov-
ernment regulations require us to reserve this working
area for your flight crew. Here they control all the pre-
cision instruments necessary in flying your giant Sky-
liner, including the up-to-the-minute radar equipment
that assures voura smooth. comfortabicament
Have You A Question?
From time to time your Captain or Hostess may
give you information over the loud speaker system
about where vou are, how high vou are flying. and how
fast you are traveling.
There are some special sounds you may wonder about.
An intermittent sound during take-offs and landings
(rather like a giant buzzer) comes from special hy-
draulic motors that operate wing flaps and landing gear
If you hear a tone change from the engines, its your
pilot adjusting the propellers to take a larger or smaller
'bite
escaping exhaust
gases-orange and red, which are visible in the dark.
You'll Enjoy Real Comfort...
If there's anything you want, just push the over-
head button to summon your Hostess. She'll be glad to
bring you a pillow or a blanket, one of the many current
magazines carried on board, or a writing kit. Why not
take advantage of this opportunity to write some picture
postcards (they're free!) which your Hostess will be
happy to mail for you? Your Hostess will also provide
games to amuse the youngsters, and warm the baby's
bottle.
Would you like some cool, fresh air? Your Hostess
wIll show you the little air vent, located above your
near Which vou can east y acius
... and Wonderful Food!
On all First Class TWA flights within the U.S.
and overseas, you enjoy delicious, hot full-course meals
served right at your seat-at no extra cost! On coach
flights in the U.S. there is a nominal charge for meals:
on international flights theres no charge. Tea, cottee,
and milk are available atallumes. And remember-onc
onte wonder uhines abou am travel- there s
tipping at any time!
On
TWA Super- Constellations and Jetstreams there's
a gleaming galley to delight the housewife in every
woman-it's complete with the very latest in refrigera-
tors and electric in-flight ovens. Your entree is served
hot-imagine that 18,000 feet in the air!
Upon Arrival In Europe
Air travel is so swift and pleasant that you'll be
across the Atlantic before you know it! When you
land, a TWA ground Hostess will welcome you at the
and.
you wish, help you through customs
and any other formalities. Don't worry about foreign
languages-your ground Hostess is a trained linguist.
If you need help in finding your way about foreign
cities, stop in at the local TWA office. They'll gladly

Upon Arrival In Europe
Air travel is so swift and pleasant that you'll be
across the Atlantic before you know it! When you
land, a TWA ground Hostess will welcome you at the
and.
you wish, help you through customs
and any other formalities. Don't worry about foreign
languages-your ground Hostess is a trained linguist.
If you need help in finding your way about foreign
cities, stop in at the local TWA office. They'll gladly

supply you with city maps, and the useful pocket-sized
TWA Travel Tips books about 8 major European
countries are available at 50c each. a set of any three
at $1.00, and all eight for $2.50.
Any TWA representative will be glad to answer your
questions and give vou information on signseems and
shopping.
any
The
TWA Ticket Office in a foreign city is also a very
convenient place to leave messages for vour friends.
Dick up vour mail exchange currency. and generally
use as a bit of home abroad
Be Sure To Reconfirm Your Reservations!
Be sure to reconnirm vour reservations a each
stopover city outside the U.S. at least 72 hours before
scheduled departure time from that city, or immediately
if vou arrive there less than 72 hours before departure
time. On flights within the U.S., the rule is: you must
reconfirm at least 6 hours before departure time at each
stopover citv. You can reconfirm your continuing reser
vations at the WA airport ticket counter on arrival,
or by telephoning the city TWA office.
Some Do's and Don'ts
Amy Vanderbilt, the etiquette authority, has given us
the followine suecestions on "plane manners.
Do's
1. When traveling alone, do give up a double seat so
that a couple may sit together.
2. Do adjust the air vent so it is not directly in the
face of your seat mate.
3. Do keep children occupied with books, games,
conversation.
4. Do feel free to remove your shoes for greater com-
or when Sleeping
5. Do ask for information about the area you are
flying over if it is of interest to you.
6. Do ask your Hostess to warm the baby's bottle.
7. During evening flights, do try to keep your voice
low, as others may be sleeping
8. Feel free to talk to fellow passengers. This is so-
cially correct among plane passengers.
9. Since yawning and chewing gum relieve pressure,
hey are perecry acceptable in plane travel.
10. When leaving the airplane, do put your seat in
erect position so that people behind you can get
out easily.
Don'ts
1. Don't forget to check before leaving the plane to
make sure you have all your belongings.
2. Don't hesitate to chat with your Hostess or Purser
during their tree moments
3. Don't forget to use your "Seat Occupied" card if
you leave the plane to stroll around at an inter-
mediate stop.
4. Don't hesitate to get off the plane at stops to have
a look around. You won't get lost, and there will
be an announcement in the terminal to give you
plenty ot time to return to your seat.
5. Don't lower your seat without first checking be-
hind you. It may jolt your neighbor's lap tray.
6. On arrival at your destination, don't leave your
seat unt the engines have come to a rulE stoo.
7. Don't forget to return magazines and newspapers
when vou are nished so ha oiners may enios
Then.
8. Don't park hand luggage in the aisle or in your
neighbor's way.
9. Don't be reluctant about fastening your napkin
(it has a buttonhole) to your shirt or blouse-the
"napkin under the chin" look is popular on planes.
10. Don't hesitate to tell your Hostess this is your first
flight. She'll be glad to point things out to you.
If you're interested in any of the following leaflets, just
check the ones vou want and send vour request to me
Let's Talk About...
Climates and Clothes
Shopping Abroad
Tipping Abroad
Traveling Solo
Traveling with Tots
0000
Stretching Your Travel Dollar
New York
California
Currency Converter
Basic Travel Wardrobes
All set for your first flight? I know you'll enjoy it-and
all the other TWA flights you take in days to come.
Welcome aboard, and happy landings!
May Gordon
TWA Travel Advisor
380 Madison Avenue
New York 17, N. Y.
